name: aptenodytes-forsteri
definition: A large penguin of Antarctic regions, having yellow-orange patches on the neck.
description:
The emperor penguin is the tallest and heaviest of all living penguin species and is endemic to Antarctica.

The male and female are similar in plumage and size, reaching 122 centimeters in height and weighing from 22 to 45 kilograms.

Feathers of the head and back are black and sharply delineated from the white belly, pale-yellow breast and bright-yellow ear patches.

Dense feathers provide 80-90% of its insulation and it has a layer of sub-dermal fat which may be up to 3 centimeters thick before breeding.

Like all penguins it is flightless, with a streamlined body, and wings stiffened and flattened into flippers for a marine habitat.

The tongue is equipped with rear-facing barbs to prevent prey from escaping when caught.

While hunting, the species can remain submerged around 20 minutes, diving to a depth of 535 meters.

It has several adaptations to facilitate this, including an unusually structured haemoglobin to allow it to function at low oxygen levels, solid bones, and the ability to reduce its metabolism.

The lifespan is typically 20 years in the wild, although observations suggest that some individuals may live to 50 years of age.

The emperor penguin has a circumpolar distribution in the Antarctic almost exclusively between the 66° and 77° south latitudes.

It almost always breeds on stable pack ice near the coast and up to 18 kilometers offshore.

Breeding colonies are usually in areas where ice cliffs and icebergs provide some protection from the wind.

Its diet consists primarily of fish, but also includes crustaceans, such as krill, and cephalopods, such as squid.

Emperor penguins is the only penguin species that breeds during the Antarctic winter.

They trek 50 to 120 kilometers over the ice to breeding colonies which can contain up to several thousand individuals.

The female lays a single egg, which is incubated for just over two months by the male while the female returns to the sea to feed.

Parents subsequently take turns foraging at sea and caring for their chick in the colony.

The emperor penguin is a social animal in its nesting and its foraging behaviour; birds hunting together may coordinate their diving and surfacing.

Individuals may be active day or night.

A mature adult travels throughout most of the year between the breeding colony and ocean foraging areas.

The species disperses into the oceans from January to March.

facts.name: Gather in large groups
facts.value: Emperor penguins gather in large groups to survive extremely cold weather without eating during the incubation period. They change position and move from the periphery to the center of the group from time to time to warm themselves up. Males can lose up to 50% of their body mass during this period.

facts.name: Can swims at 12 kilometers per hour
facts.value: Emperor penguin swims at the speed of 12 kilometers per hour. It can dive to a depth of 535 meters and stay under the water for up to 20 minutes.

facts.name: Emperor penguin is carnivore
facts.value: Emperor penguin is a carnivore. Its diet is based on krill, squids and fish.

facts.name: Can reach 1.3 meters in height
facts.value: Emperor penguin can reach 1.1 to 1.3 meters in height and 22 to 45 kilograms of weight.

facts.name: Has black head and back
facts.value: Emperor penguin has black head and back, white belly, pale yellow breasts and yellow ear patches. It has four layers of scale-like, oily and waterproof feathers and thick layer of blubber which ensure survival on a temperature of minus 60 degrees of Celsius.

facts.name: Female lays one egg and goes for food
facts.value: Female lays one egg and returns to the sea to collect food, while male takes care of the egg during the entire period of incubation which lasts 70 days. Male holds egg on top of the feet and keeps it warm with a layer of feathered skin called brood pouch.

facts.name: Monogamous pairs per season
facts.value: Emperor penguins form monogamous pairs that usually last only one season.

facts.name: Can survive 15 to 20 years in the wild
facts.value: Emperor penguin can survive 15 to 20 years in the wild. It is believe that exceptional individuals can reach 50 years.

facts.name: Walking on two legs
facts.value: Emperor penguin moves on the solid ground by walking on two legs and gliding on the belly.

facts.name: Fledge at the age of 5 to 6 months
facts.value: Young emperor penguins fledge at the age of 5 to 6 months and reach sexual maturity at the age of 3 years.

facts.name: Natural enemies
facts.value: Natural enemies of emperor penguins are seabirds (giant petrels and skuas), killer whales and leopard seals.

facts.name: Males produce courtship calls
facts.value: Males move their heads and produce courtship calls to attract females.

facts.name: The only species that mates on winter
facts.value: Emperor penguin is the only species of penguin that mates during the coldest period of the year. It travels up to 80 kilometers away from the sea at the beginning of the winter toward the more stable breeding areas.

facts.name: Has small black beak with orange line
facts.value: Emperor penguin has small black beak with orange-yellow line that runs lengthwise, small, stiff flippers, aerodynamic body and webbed feet with sharp claws.

facts.name: Females return when chicks hatch
facts.value: Females return to the colony when chicks hatch. They feed them with half-digested food. Males then travel back to the sea, while females stays with their chicks and keep them warm with their own brood pouches until they become old enough to stay in the crèches with other youngsters.
